results.abstract: "The Autobiography of Nicolae Ceausescu," playing out of competition at the Cannes Film Festival, is the third in a series of documentaries that the Romanian-born Andrei Ujica has made about the death of communism.

headline.main: A Dictator in His Own Words and Images

results.snippet: "The Autobiography of Nicolae Ceausescu," playing out of competition at the Cannes Film Festival, is the third in a series of documentaries that the Romanian-born Andrei Ujica has made about the death of communism.
results.lead_paragraph: CANNES, France - As the title suggests, "The Autobiography of Nicolae Ceausescu" is hardly a conventional historical documentary. Andrei Ujica's three-hour-plus found-footage epic, screening out of competition at the Cannes Film Festival, recounts the life of the Romanian dictator as Ceausescu himself saw it - or, as was often the case, stage-managed it. Devoid of explanatory titles and voice-overs, the film assembles a composite portrait of Ceausescu solely through the existing visual record: the speeches he gave, the parades thrown in his honor, the state visits he made (to the United States, China, Britain and, most memorably, North Korea) and the home movies of family vacations and hunting expeditions.
